“Why are you so pale, Rodion Romanovitch?” 

Raskolnikov shifted uncomfortably. 

“Is the room stuffy? Shall I open the window?” 

He hesitated, then laughed nervously. 

“Please don’t trouble.” 

Porfiry chuckled, but Raskolnikov's legs trembled. 

He stood, trying to appear composed. 

“I see clearly. You suspect me of murder.” 

Porfiry’s smile faded. 

“Interesting, isn’t it? The cleverest man can betray himself.” 

Raskolnikov’s heart raced. 

He felt exposed, like a reflection in a mirror.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The passage explores how a person's temperament can betray them, even when they attempt to deceive others with cleverness and wit.
